question: A square loop of side length 'a' is moving away from an infinitely long current carrying conductor at a constant speed 'v' as shown. Let 'x' be the instantaneous distance between the long conductor and side AB. The mutual inductance (M) of the square loop - long conductor pair changes with time (t) according to which of the following graphs?
images/e4d3c2b1-a1b2-4c3d-8e9f-000000000002.png
choices: Graph showing M decreasing exponentially with t
Graph showing M increasing linearly with t
Graph showing M constant with t
Graph showing M decreasing linearly with t
explanation: Mutual inductance <katex>$M$</katex> depends on the flux linkage per unit current.
The magnetic field <katex>$B$</katex> due to the long wire decreases as <katex>$1/x$</katex>.
As the loop moves away, <katex>$x = vt$</katex>, so the flux <katex>$\phi$</katex> and thus <katex>$M$</katex> decrease non-linearly (logarithmically/inversely) with distance/time.
The graph A shows a non-linear decay, which is the correct representation.
